Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk perl-Test-Warn
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: perl-Test-Warn bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description:
An updated perl-Test-Warn package that fixes one bug is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. The perl-Test-Warn package provides convenience methods for testing warning-based code.
This update fixes the following bug:
* Prior to this update, the perl-Test-Warn package was missing some buildtime and runtime dependencies. Consequently, building the package or using the Test::Warn module could fail on attempting to use a Perl module that was not installed. To fix this bug, the missing dependencies have been added and constrained with appropriate minimal versions where appropriate. As a result, the perl-Test-Warn package dependencies are now correct. (BZ#1066456)
Users of perl-Test-Warn are advised to upgrade to this updated package, which fixes this bug.
Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
